_exec_summary.SummaryText:

The industrial facilities in Calvert City, the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC), and the Calvert City Fire Department have also established a system for warning the community if an accident occurs that could threaten the community.
     
     ISP's Site General Manager has overall responsibility for the development and implementation of the Risk Management Program for EPA-regulated processes at their respective facilities.  However, the specific responsibilities for certain aspects of that program have been delegated by the Site General Manager to other personnel who report either directly, or through other management personnel, to the Site General Manager.  Those relationships are depicted on an organization chart.  Specific responsibility for the implementation of the Process Safety Management (PSM), accident prevention program, RMP hazard assessment and Risk Management Plan has been delegated jointly to the Environmental Compliance Director, Safety-Health & Security Manager, and Sr. Safety Engineer.  In keeping with our policy that safe operation is part of everyone?s job, many other personnel are also involved in RMP activities on an ongoing basis.

1.2		ISP's Calvert City Plant Regulated Substances

     The ISP Calvert City Plant is a chemical manufacturing facility located in the Purchase Area of far Western Kentucky, in Calvert City, in northern Marshall County.

1.  EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

     The ISP Calvert City Plant is committed to operating in a manner that is safe for Calvert City Plant workers, the public, and the environment.  As a member of the American Chemistry Council and the Synthetic Organic Chemical Manufacturers Association, ISP implements the principles of Responsible Care? to ensure a safe and environmentally sound operation.  The ISP Calvert City Plant has been RC14001 certified since November 2007.   In addition, as part of this commitment, the Calvert City Plant has established systems to help ensure safe operation of the processes at this facility.  One part of these systems is a Risk Management Program (RMP) that helps manage the risks at ISP's Calvert City Plant and that complies with the requirements of the Environmental Protection Agency?s (EPA?s) rule 40 CFR part 68, Accidental Release Prevention Requirements: Risk Management Programs (the RMP rule). One of the requirements of the RMP rule is to submit a Risk Management Plan (RMPlan) describing the Risk Management Program at the Calvert City Plant.  This document is intended to satisfy the RMPlan executive summary requirements of the RMP rule and to provide the public with a description of that Risk Management Program.

1.1		Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

     The ISP Calvert City Plant is committed to the safety of workers and the public, and to the preservation of the environment, through the prevention of accidental releases of hazardous substances. The Plant implements reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of hazardous substances. In the event of a significant accidental release, our trained personnel will respond to control and contain such releases.  The Plant evaluates each situation, evacuates workers as necessary, responds based on our capabilities, skills and training, and if necessary, contacts the local Mutual Aid Association, Calvert Industrial Mutual Aid Program (CIMAP), to assist in control
